Entities.text: Excessive time spent on reporting to show control (e.g., >6 hours/week per PO/lead)
Insufficient time spent on understanding user needs (e.g., discovery/refinement <8 hours/Sprint/PO)
Significant rework during refinement (e.g., >2 rework cycles/PBI to reach Ready)
POs often lack time to prepare for sprints (prep hours < threshold before Sprint Planning)
Deliveries are in large slices (batch size large: releases include many PBIs or span multiple components)
Many PBIs do not meet Definition of Ready (e.g., <80% DoR compliance at Sprint start)
PBIs scope and objectives documented inconsistently (missing/ambiguous AC, objectives)
PBIs estimated inconsistently (units/scales differ; high variance)
Estimates do not allow comparison of PBI sizes (apples-to-oranges)
PBIs counted toward performance often do not meet Definition of Done
Past performance cannot reliably predict future deliveries (forecast error high)
Delivery is unpredictable (high lead time variability; low schedule adherence)
Work is rushed to meet delivery dates (preemptions, overtime, scope compression)
Technical debt keeps growing
Impediments and unplanned work keep increasing or remain volatile
Past performance poorly predicts future performance and tends to over-estimate capability
We often take short-cuts (skip tests/refactoring, manual workarounds)
We deliver low quality (escaped defects, failure rates)
We have high levels of rework (defect fixes, re-analysis)
Effective development capacity is low (net available hours for new work reduced)
Throughput is low (completed PBIs/Sprint below demand)
Value-delivery is low (value points/release below target)
We lack a production-like ad-hoc test environment
We cannot test against a stable known configuration (environment drift, non-reproducible builds)
We often need code freezes
Code freezes distort or invalidate estimates
We have excessive work-in-progress (WIP above capacity; many items in progress)
We spend insufficient time on QA in the teams or QA delays deliveries
We have little time to work on improving our processes
Our processes remain sub-optimal
Stakeholder trust in our delivery is low
We spend little time working on value-driving work
We scope features inconsistently (poor slicing; variable granularity)
PO time budget per Sprint is fixed (capacity constraint on PO hours)
PO discovery/refinement time < target (hours diverted from discovery)
Insufficient Ready PBIs available at Sprint start
Late/insufficient Ready items cause bundling into larger releases
Acceptance criteria/test cases missing or inconsistent
Estimation scales or reference classes differ across teams
Performance metric (velocity/throughput) is inflated/noisy (includes not-Done items; apples-to-oranges)
Forecasts/plans are based on noisy or invalid metrics
Fixed-date commitments exist (external promises, deadlines)
Expedite/preemption policy is used when behind schedule
Environment/integration drift high (no immutable, prod-like baseline)
Integration failures/test flakiness rate is high
Code freeze instituted to stabilize baseline (stop-the-line policy)
Freeze introduces wait states/queue ageing for in-progress work
Estimates become stale due to unplanned waits/scope churn
No WIP cap / start-to-keep-busy policy (push system)
High WIP drives high flow variability (long, variable queues)
Reporting demand increases when trust is low (status/control reporting)
Under fixed-date pressure, test scope/time is compressed (late testing, reduced coverage)

Quick Consistency Checks: All UDEs still explained: Yes. Unpredictability (E12), low quality (E18), low value (E22), low trust (E31), excessive WIP (E27) are reachable via short, mechanistic chains.

Core driver(s) unique and minimally sufficient: Candidate drivers are policies E49 (no WIP cap) and E42/E43 (fixed-date + expedite), plus measurement policy E40/E41. Each is modeled explicitly with mechanisms.
Hidden policy constraints unresolved: Existence/value of fixed-date policy (E42), expedite rules (E43), WIP cap policy (E49), DoR content (E38), estimation scale alignment (E39).

Measurements available to validate: WIP count, lead time variance, percent DoR compliance, AC completeness rate, estimate scale alignment across teams, fraction of not-Done counted in performance, hours/week on reporting vs discovery, freeze days/Sprint, queue ageing during freeze, forecast error vs actual.
